Herein, sulfonated Zr-based metal-organic frameworks (MOF-808), a bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst with Lewis and Bronsted acid sites, were prepared to catalyze the one-pot cascade reaction of furfural (FUR) to GVL. The successful modification of the sulfonic group on MOF-808 was substantiated by multiple characterization methods. By adjusting the sulfuric acid concentration to balance the Lewis acid and Bronsted acid sites of the catalyst, S-808–2.37 was confirmed as the preferred catalyst and a 60.4 % GVL yield was achieved with 99.1 % carbon balance under the optimal conditions. Moreover, the 72.8 % GVL yield reached in the 40x magnification experiment also boded well for the catalyst’s application potential. The work in this paper opened up new perspectives for the application of MOF-808 porous materials in the field of selective catalytic conversion of biomass involving multi-step reactions. Graphical Abstract Bifunctional zirconium-based metal-organic frameworks as chemoselective catalysts for the synthesis of γ-valerolactone from furfural via a one-pot cascade reaction. ga1 Keywords Biomass utilization Metal-organic framework Biofuels Transfer hydrogenation γ-valerolactone Cascade reaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With global environmental pollution and the growing consumption of fossil energy, it was particularly important to find green routes for the synthesis of chemicals and fuels [1]. The utilization and transformation of lignocellulosic biomass (cellulose, hemicellulose and lignin) was an attractive route for the synthesis of high-value fuels and renewable chemicals in the future [2–6]. FUR was an abundant low-cost bio-derivative of xylose derived from hemicellulose hydrolysis through acid-catalyzed dehydration and a feedstock for the production of high-value-added platform compounds (including levulinic acid, γ-valerolactone, etc.) [7–10]. Among these platform compounds, γ-valerolactone (GVL) had received extensive attention due to its capability to be transformed into a variety of chemicals, such as a synthetic intermediate for food additives and green solvents, a platform molecule for the production of liquid fuels, etc [11–13]. The synthesis of GVL from FUR could be carried out in an acid-catalyzed reaction system ( Scheme 1) comprising multiple discrete chemical transformations, each driven by a specific catalyst. The synthesis was difficult to be industrialized due to the involvement of a series of intermediates and competitive side reactions, so the one-pot cascade conversion of FUR to GVL was highlighted [14]. The conversion not only eliminated the need for the separation of intermediates but also reduced the use of solvents, which enhanced the sustainability of the conversion [7,15]. In Scheme 1, the second and fourth step reactions were traditionally hydrogen reduction reactions catalyzed by the zero-valent metal catalyst [13,16–22]. Owing to well-known reasons (the danger of hydrogen, the difficulty of storing zero-valent metals, etc.), catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) reaction with alcohol instead of H2 as the hydrogen source became an ideal alternative [23–28], e.g., Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verley (MPV) reaction with the advantages of atmospheric pressure reaction and the use of low-cost alcohol as both hydrogen source and solvent [29]. The one-pot conversion of FUR to GVL with alcohols as the hydrogen source involved complex multi-step cascade reactions. And the synergistic effect of Lewis and Bronsted acid-sites of catalysts was instrumental in catalyzing the reaction. Melero et al. prepared bifunctional Zr/Al-Beta zeolites to catalyze the reaction of FUR to GVL in isopropanol (IPA) with a GVL yield of 22.6 % after 24 h at 170 °C [30]. A yield of GVL reached 37 % at 170 °C for 7 h in the presence of the ZrO2-SBA-15 catalyst synthesized by Iglesias et al [7]. Based on SCM-1 zeolite, a Zr-Al-SCM-1 zeolite catalyst manufactured by dealumination followed by zirconium doping was applied to the cascade reaction with 47.3 % of GVL yield as well as 85.6 % of carbon balance after 28 h at 170 °C [31]. With the combination of Al-MFI-ns and Al-MFI zeolites, a 68 % yield of GVL at 120 °C for 48 h was achieved [32]. Al-HY and dealuminated Zr-HY zeolite by impregnation as Bronsted acid catalyst and Lewis acid catalyst, respectively, were synthesized for the one-pot conversion of FUR to GVL in IPA under nitrogen atmosphere, acquiring a GVL yield of 85 % at 120 °C for 5 h [6]. The reaction system was catalyzed by noble metal Hf-based DUT-67–0.06 catalyst to obtain 87.1 % GVL yield at 180 °C for 24 h [33]. With phosphotungstic acid loaded Zr-Beta zeolite as a catalyst, the yield of GVL was 70 % at 160 ℃ after 24 h [34]. Additionally, other bifunctional catalysts (e.g., Zr-KIT-5-(10), SZN-5-O, HZ-ZrP1–16 and Sn-Al-Beta, etc.) were also explored for the cascade reaction system (Table S2) [35–38]. Studies of sulfonated MOF-catalyzed biomass conversion generally focused on a specific MPV reaction [39], e.g., hydrogenation reactions of FUR to FOL [28,40] or LA/LAE to GVL [41]. Therefore, the cascade reaction of GVL from FUR via the MPV route was more efficient and economical from the point of view of avoiding the separation of intermediates and reducing the cost of GVL batch production.[42,43]. In recent years zirconium-based metal-organic frameworks (Zr-MOFs) had attracted extensive research interest due to their significant advantages in terms of their structural diversity and unique physicochemical properties [41,44–48]. Particularly, MOF-808 exhibited good catalytic potential among Zr-MOFs as a result of its low metal nodes to ligand coordination (coordination number 6) as well as its large specific surface area [48–55]. In the crystal structure of MOF-808, a 3D porous framework was formed by each 6-linked Zr cluster linked to six BTC (1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate), and each formate group bridged two zirconium atoms for the formation of a six-membered ring around the Zr cluster [56]. By changing the binding mode of grafted species, the Brønsted acidity of MOF-808 could be modulated, which facilitated the development of new acid-base catalysts [45]. Among them, since the modification of the unsaturated Zr6 node of MOF-808 with sulfuric acid could significantly improve its Brønsted acidity ( Fig. 1) [57], S-808 was often applied to proton conductivity improvement, ion trapping, liquid flow battery membranes and other fields [58–61]. Moreover, the easy deactivation of the catalyst caused by the production of some oligomers was a non-negligible problem, as well as the stability of the catalyst in non-homogeneous catalytic systems [62]. Considering these factors, given the poor stability of heterogeneous catalysts in the reaction system and its incapability of large-scale production, here, a sulfonated MOF-808 (S-808) with a high specific surface area was prepared as a catalyst and applied to a one-pot cascade reaction system from FUR to GVL. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials ZrOCl2·8H2O (AR, 99 %), 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (H3BDC, 98 %) and FUR (AR, 99 %) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation. Furfuryl alcohol (FOL, AR, 99 %), levulinic acid (98 %), levulinate esters (>98 %) and γ-valerolactone (98 % %) were purchased from TCI Chemical Reagent Company (Shanghai, China). Methanol (AR, ≥99.5 %), ethanol (AR, ≥99.7 %), n-propanol (AR, ≥99.5 %), isopropyl alcohol (IPA, AR, ≥99.7 %), n-butanol (AR, ≥99.5 %), sec-butanol (AR, ≥99 %), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, 99.5 %), H2SO4 (AR, 98.0 %), formic acid (88 %), Zr(OH)4 (AR, 97 %) and ZrO2 (AR) were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Company (Shanghai, China). Thick-walled pressure-resistant bottles were purchased from Beijing Xavier Glass Instruments Co. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of MOF-808 MOF-808 was prepared according to a typical procedure [57,63,64]. Briefly, ZrOCl2·8H2O (0.48 g) and H3BTC (0.33 g) were dissolved in 30 mL DMF, respectively, and then the two solutions were mixed in a 200 mL beaker. After 60 mL of formic acid was added, the mixture was transferred into a 200 mL stainless steel reactor lined with PTFE at 140 °C for 24 h. After the reaction, the collected white precipitate was first washed 3 times with DMF to remove unreacted ligand molecules from the pores of MOF-808, then 3 times with anhydrous ethanol to remove DMF, and finally 3 times with deionized water. The resulting solid was dried at 80 °C overnight. 2.2.2 Preparation of S-808 Sulfonated MOF-808 (S-808) was synthesized by modifying MOF-808 with sulfuric acid [56,57]. The synthesized MOF-808 (0.2 g) was immersed in 20 mL of the sulfuric acid solution for 24 h with regular stirring. The resulting solid collected by filtration was washed three times with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, respectively, and dried at 80 °C overnight. For sulfuric acid concentrations of 0.025 M, 0.05 M, 0.1 M, 0.2 M and 0.4 M, the corresponding catalyst were labeled as S-808-x (x = 1.69, 2.37, 2.62, 2.75 and 2.82, respectively, where x is the number of sulfate groups per secondary building unit). 2.3 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a Rigaku D/max-2550 diffractometer (Cu-Kα radiation from 10 ° to 80 °). Low-pressure N2 adsorption isotherms were measured on an Asap 2420 surface adsorption apparatus, and liquid nitrogen and argon baths were used for the measurements at 77 K. Carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen and sulfur elemental microanalyses (EA) were performed in the Microanalytical Laboratory with a Perkin Elmer 2400 Series II CHNS elemental analyzer. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) and Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using Jeol JSM-6700 F and Tecnai F20, respectively. An aqueous suspension of the sample was prepared and a small drop of the diluted suspension was dried on a TEM copper grid coated with a carbon film. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted with PerkinElmer Instruments in air, and weight loss data were normalized to the weight of the final oxide. FT-IR spectroscopy was collected on a Bruker VERTEXV80 V spectrometer in the wavenumber range 400 cm-1 to 4000 cm-1. Determination of the elemental composition and content of catalysts was completed by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) on an Optima 3300dv (Perkin Elmer). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was implemented on an ESCALAB 250 spectrometer with a monochromatic Mg Kα x-ray source. Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 and CO2 (NH3/CO2-TPD) were analyzed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) temperature of 50–400 °C, and all samples were treated at 150 °C for 5 h before testing. Pyridine adsorption Fourier transform infrared (Py-FTIR) tests were recorded at ambient temperature in air on a Jasco FT/IR-410 using a KBr dispersion of a 420 Herschel series. Samples were processed at 350 °C for 1 h and then ramped up to 150 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min for testing. 2.4 Catalytic test The reaction was carried out in 15 mL thick-walled pressure-resistant bottles. In a typical run, furfural (16 mg), S-808 (25 mg) and IPA (5 mL) were each charged into the bottle and sealed. The bottle was heated to the desired temperature (140–180 °C) with strong stirring (600 rpm) for a period of time (1–10 h). After the reaction, the reactor was quickly cooled to ambient temperature, and the reaction solution after removal of the catalyst by filtration was analyzed by TRACE ISQ GC-MS (Thermo Scientific Co) on a TR-WAX-MS column (Thermo Scientific Co, TR-WAX-MS column 30.0 m × 320 µm × 0.25 µm). And the temperature program started at 60 °C for 1 min, then increased from 60 °C to 230 °C at a rate of 15 °C/min and held for 2 min. The conversion of FUR, the yield and the selectivity of GVL were defined as follows: Conversion % = mole of FUR reacted mole of starting FUR × 100 % Yield % = moles of GVL produced moles of starting FUR × 100 % Selectivity ( % ) = moles of GVL produced moles of reacted FUR × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Among many Zr MOFs, MOF-808 was selected and applied to CTH (catalytic transfer hydrogenation) reaction due to its large pore size and strong acidity [65]. The structural characterizations of MOF-808 synthesized in this experiment were listed in Fig. 2. The XRD spectra (Fig. 2a) confirmed the successful synthesis of MOF-808 [63,65,66]. The type of N2 adsorption and desorption curves of the catalysts (Fig. 2b) were type I, and the pore size distribution plots showed that the pore sizes of the catalysts were dominated by micropores (< 2 nm), accompanied by a small amount of mesopores (2–20 nm) (Fig. 2c). In the FT-IR spectrum of Fig. 2d, the absorption bands appeared at 1133 and 1250 cm-1 were assigned to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations of OSO bonding and the enhanced band at 993 and 1048 cm-1 are associated with the stretching mode of SO bonding [28,33,41,67,68], while the disappearance of the stretching and deformation vibrations of saturated –OH (located at 2876 cm-1 and 1110 cm-1 in MOF-808) further verified that the sulfonic group was modified to MOF-808 by forming a Zr–O–S bond [56,57,63]. From the TGA and DTG curves (Fig. 2e and Fig. 2f) of MOF-808 and S-808–2.37, the weight loss of MOF-808 was divided into three temperature intervals (60 ℃–150 °C, 250 ℃–420 °C and 510 ℃–650 °C), which corresponded to the weight loss of adsorbed water, the decomposition of organic matter, as well as the destruction of the MOF-808 structure, respectively. The weight loss of S-808-2.37 in the 60 ℃–150 °C interval was significantly more than that of MOF-808, its final remaining weight was less than that of MOF-808, which also proved the interaction between sulfonic groups and MOF-808. The physicochemical properties of the catalysts were surveyed in Table 1. Zr- 808 had the largest specific surface area (1257 m2/g) and pore volume (0.7219 cm3/g) (Entry 1, Table 1). The decline in specific surface area and pore volume of S-808 was caused by the gap-filling effect of the sulfonic group, further confirming the successful modification of MOF-808 by sulfonic group [41]. For purpose of comparing the acid-base intensities of the active sites in different catalysts, the full spectrum and the elemental environments of zirconium and oxygen in different catalysts were analyzed by XPS techniques ( Fig. 3). Four elements Zr, O, C and S were present in S-808–2.37 (Fig. 3a), and the binding energies of zirconium in S-808-2.37 (182.90 eV for 3d5/2 and 185.30 eV for 3d3/2) were greater than those of MOF-808, Zr(OH)4 and ZrO2 (Fig. 3b), which meant that the zirconium atoms in S-808-2.37 had the highest positive charge and thus the strongest Lewis acidity [24]. Furthermore, the binding energy of O 1 s (531.76 eV) belonging to the –Zr–O–Ar– (Ar, benzene ring) coordination interactions in S-808-2.37 was higher than that of -Zr-O-Zr- in ZrO2 (530.05 eV). The medium binding energy of O1s attributed to the negative charge on the oxygen atom declared the medium Lewis base strength of S-808-2.37 [25]. In addition, the high-resolution XPS spectrum of S 2p (Fig. 3d), the peaks at 168.95 eV and 170.18 eV could be ascribed to S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2, respectively. The above changes proved that S was introduced onto MOF-808 without affecting the structure of the framework, which enhanced the Lewis acid-base strength of the catalyst and thus facilitated the adsorption and activation of the substrate on the surface of the catalyst. The morphology of the catalysts was observed by SEM and TEM images ( Fig. 4). As shown in Fig. 4a–b and e, MOF-808 were particles with a smooth surface between 100 and 150 nm in diameter. After sulfonation, the particle diameter and smoothness fell slightly due to the corrosive effect of sulfuric acid on the catalyst surface (Fig. 4c–d and f). In addition, SEM-EDS and elemental mapping revealed uniform distribution of Zr, O and S elements on the surface of S-808-2.37 (Fig. 4g-4h). And the contents of Zr, C and S were consistent with the results of ICP and CHNS elemental analysis (Table 1). The acidity of the catalysts was examined by ammonia adsorption and the infrared spectrum of pyridine. The sulfonation of MOF-808 led to the increase of catalyst acidity first and then decreased with the increase of sulfuric acid concentration ( Fig. 5a). The higher NH3/CO2 desorption indicated that S-808–2.37 had a higher acid-base site content (7.149 mmol/g and 2930.89 μmol/g respectively) compared to MOF-808, these results also demonstrated that the prepared S-808–2.37 had more acid-base sites than the other S-808 catalysts (Table 1), which was attributed to the effect of sulfonation on the electron strength around Zr and O in the catalyst, which in turn reflected the effect on the catalyst acidity and basicity. While the descent in acidity and basicity at a higher sulfuric acid concentration (>0.05 mol/L) was caused by the corrosion of catalyst surface by sulfuric acid. For a comprehensive understanding of the acidic sites of the catalyst, FT-IR spectroscopy of pyridine adsorption for identifying the Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites was carried out in a vacuum at the specified desorption temperature of 150 °C (Fig. 5b). From Fig. 5b, five peaks located at 1440, 1490, 1540, 1610 and 1640 cm-1 were described as the interaction of the pyridine with either the Lewis acid sites or the Brønsted acid sites in the catalyst or both acid sites together, respectively. The Lewis acid sites in MOF-808 were mainly derived from Zr4+, and the Brønsted acid sites could be from the –SO3 functional group and H3BDC in the MOF [41]. After sulfonation, the introduction of the sulfonic group resulted in the elevation of the Brønsted acid of MOF-808 and more positive charge on Zr4+, followed by the enhancement in Lewis acid (the B/L ratio increased from 0.35 in MOF-808–0.86 in S-808–2.37), which was also confirmed by XPS results. 3.2 Catalytic performance evaluation of various catalysts The catalytic performance evaluation of different catalysts was listed in Table 2. As expected, FUR did not react without a catalyst (Table 2, Entry 1). With multiple zirconium-containing compounds (ZrO2, Zr(OH)4 and MOF-808) as catalysts (Table 2, Entries 2–4), neither i-PL nor GVL could be produced, only FOL with increasing yields (from 26.3 % to 93.7 %). The fact that the reaction of FOL from FUR was a Lewis acid-catalyzed MPV reaction manifested that the amount of Lewis acid rose gradually and few Brønsted acid sites for these three catalysts (ZrO2, Zr(OH)4 and MOF-808). Changing the substrate to LA (Table 2, Entry 5), more than 99 % conversion of LA and 92.4 % yield of GVL further demonstrated that MOF-808 was an excellent catalyst for MPV reaction due to its strong Lewis acidity, but its small amount of Bronsted acid sites was not enough to drive the ring-opening reaction of FOL. Moreover, the introduction of Brønsted acid sites through sulfonation not only opened the subsequent transformation from FOL to GVL, but also improved the carbon balance of the reaction to 99.1 % with 60.4 % GVL yield and 38.7 % i-PL yield (Table 2, Entry 6), which was higher than most reported works (Table S2). However, when S-808–2.37 was replaced with catalysts mixed in different ratios S-808–2.37 and MOF-808 (4:1 and 3:2) without changing the catalyst dosage, FUR could not effectively complete the subsequent conversion (Table 2, Entry 7–8), which was attributed to the decrease in Bronsted acid sites and the attenuation of the synergistic effect caused by the increasing distance between Lewis acid sites and Bronsted acid sites [16]. The optimization of the catalytic reaction conditions (reaction time, reaction temperature, catalyst dosage and alcohol source) was accomplished ( Figs. 6 and S3). After 1 h, the conversion of FUR in the catalytic reactions at different temperatures remained almost at 100 %, while the yield of GVL increased with the increase of reaction temperature and time, reaching 60.4 % at 160 °C for 4 h. Higher temperature (180 °C) after 4 h contributed less to the improvement in the yield of GVL (increased by only 1.7 % relative to 160 °C) (Fig.S3a). Moreover, the carbon balance of the reaction reached a maximum of 99.1 % at 160 °C for 4 h, and the subsequent decrease was attributed to the fact that the product tended to polymerize at too high temperature to form humins (Fig. S3c). Hence, taking into account the GVL yield and carbon balance, 160 °C for 4 h was determined as the optimum reaction condition. In Fig. 6a, the conversion of FUR, yields of PL and GVL increased with catalyst dosage (0.005–0.015 g). As the continued rise of the catalyst dosage (0.015–0.035 g), the GVL yield rose while the PL yield fell with the conversion remaining constant (100 %). The above results showed that the effect of temperature and reaction time on the reaction system was greater than that of the catalyst dosage. The influence of the alcohol source on the reaction system was reflected in Fig. 6b. With primary alcohol (methanol, ethanol, n-propanol and n-butanol) as the alcohol source, the yield of GVL was low (0–7.0 %), and the main product was levulinic acid esters (LAE) whose yield ascended first and then descended with the growth of carbon chain. The GVL yields (60.4 % and 39.3 %) and carbon balances (99.1 % and 85.6 %) of secondary alcohols (IPA and 2-butanol) as alcohol sources were remarkably superior to those of primary alcohols as alcohol sources. This fact indicated that the primary alcohol was favorable for the occurrence of the acetalization reaction, while the secondary alcohols were beneficial for the MPV reaction. Subsequently, the yield of GVL declined slightly as the carbon number of secondary alcohol increased. This might be because the longer the carbon chain of the secondary alcohol, the more pronounced spatial site-blocking effect, which impeded diffusion of the substrate molecules into the channel of the catalyst [69]. Therefore, IPA was the preferred hydrogen donor and solvent for the reaction system. 3.3 Stability of the catalyst and scale-up experiments Leaching experiments examining catalyst heterogeneity were carried out under optimized reaction conditions ( Fig. 7a). The catalyst was filtered off 3 h after the start of the reaction, after which the yield of GVL remained at 45.5 % and the reaction was stopped. After the catalyst was re-added to the reaction system, the reaction continued, and the yield of GVL went up with the reaction time. The results of ICP-OES analysis for zirconium and sulfur elements also revealed no significant compositional change in the filtered catalyst, verifying the heterogeneity of the catalyst. The conclusion of the cycle stability of the catalyst at 160 °C for 4 h (Fig. 7b) was that after 5 cycles, the FUR conversion retained 100 %, and the yield of GVL dropped a little from 60.4 % to 52.1 %. The characterization results of the catalysts after five cycles were compared with those of the pristine catalyst. After five cycles, the intensity of the diffraction peaks in the XRD pattern of the catalyst became weaker and the specific surface area decreased, which was ascribed to the accumulation of nonvolatile by-products on the catalyst surface and within the pore channels (Fig. S4a-c and Table S1). To depict the application potential of the catalyst, a scale-up experiment with a 40x magnification of the catalyst dosage, furfural mass and solvent volume was accomplished at 160 °C for 4 h (Fig. 7c). The experimental results revealed that the yield of GVL rose with reaction time (from 2.6 % in 1 h to 72.8 % in 12 h), while the yield of i-PL formed a volcano-like trend concerning reaction time (the maximum value is 26.3 % at 3 h), demonstrating that the catalyst had prospects for industrial application. 3.4 Investigation of reaction pathways and mechanisms MOF-808, with molecular formula Zr6O5(OH)3(BTC)2(HCOO)5(OH2)2, was comprised of hexacoordinated Zr6O5(OH)3 clusters three-dimensionally linked by μ3-O and μ3-OH groups [63,70]. Around the zirconium clusters, formate ions and zirconium atoms coordinated to form a six-membered belt to achieve charge equilibrium [63,71]. In dilute sulfuric acid, the sulfonic group exchanged with the formate ion on the zirconium cluster and coordinated with two zirconium atoms in a bridging mode to give S-808 ( Fig. 8) [57,72]. Based on the structure of MOF-808 and the experimental results, a possible mechanism for the one-pot conversion of FUR to GVL catalyzed by S-808 was proposed ( Scheme 2). Firstly, FUR and IPA adsorbed on the surface of S-808 interacted with the Zr4+-O2- bonds, and the carbonyl group on FUR was activated and a transition state of a six-membered ring was formed on the catalyst surface [33]. And then, the H on IPA was transferred to the FUR to give FOL. Secondly, FOL was condensed with IPA to FE under the action of acid [6]. Next, furan-2-ylmethylium cation (C5H5O+) was formed by removing IPA from FE under the action of acid, followed by forming the intermediate AL through a series of reactions such as rearrangement, hydration, dehydrogenation and oxidation [34]. Subsequently, the intermediate AL immediately underwent ring-opening and hydrogenation and esterification with IPA to produce i-PL. Finally, the intermediate 4-hydroxypentanoate, which was rapidly generated via the MPV reaction of i-PL, lactonized to afford GVL with the release of IPA [31,73]. 4 Conclusion A bifunctional catalyst S-808 with a high specific surface area and pore volume for the one-pot cascade reaction of FUR to GVL was synthesized by hydrothermal and post-synthetic modification methods. The synergistic effect of Lewis acid-base sites in Zr6O5(OH)3 cluster catalyzing the MPV reaction and Brønsted acid sites (sulfonic groups modified around the zirconium clusters) catalyzing the acid-driven reaction endowed the catalyst with the desired catalytic performance — 60.4 % GVL yield and 99.1 % carbon balance with 100 % FUR conversion under optimal conditions (160 °C for 4 h). The reactivity of the catalyst was closely related to the ratio and distance between the Lewis and Bronsted acid sites. The 100 % FUR conversion and 72.8 % GVL yield in the 40-fold scale-up experiment, as well as the slightly reduced GVL yield after five cycles, illustrated the potential application of the catalyst. A feasible mechanism was proposed based on the synergistic effect of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites and the structure of S-808–2.37. This study provided a sustainable reaction route for the application of porous MOF materials as catalysts in the field of biomass chemical conversion under mild conditions. coredata.dc:description: The transformation of lignocellulosic biomass to platform compounds (γ-valerolactone, GVL) was a significant component in biomass development. Herein, sulfonated Zr-based metal-organic frameworks (MOF-808), a bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst with Lewis and Bronsted acid sites, were prepared to catalyze the one-pot cascade reaction of furfural (FUR) to GVL. The successful modification of the sulfonic group on MOF-808 was substantiated by multiple characterization methods. By adjusting the sulfuric acid concentration to balance the Lewis acid and Bronsted acid sites of the catalyst, S-808–2.37 was confirmed as the preferred catalyst and a 60.4 % GVL yield was achieved with 99.1 % carbon balance under the optimal conditions. Moreover, the 72.8 % GVL yield reached in the 40x magnification experiment also boded well for the catalyst’s application potential. The work in this paper opened up new perspectives for the application of MOF-808 porous materials in the field of selective catalytic conversion of biomass involving multi-step reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Bifunctional zirconium-based metal-organic frameworks as chemoselective catalysts for the synthesis of γ-valerolactone from furfural via a one-pot cascade reaction
